results.title: Book bargain
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and GPO Film Unit
results.brief_description: Set inside a printing factory in the mid 1930’s, this film documents the production of the London telephone directory. Commencing with the preparation of blank rolls of paper, the film progresses through each stage of the production until the directory is ready for delivery. Captures the working conditions and technology of a printing factory in Great Britain in the mid 30’s. Made by Norman McLaren while he was working for Britain’s General Post Office in the 1930s, this film is a novel attempt to inject some interest into what may be considered a dull subject.

results.title: Boogie doodle
results.brief_description: An animated film, made without the use of a camera, in which boogie” played by Albert Ammons and synchronized with “doodle drawn by McLaren, frame by frame directly onto film stock, combine to make a rhythmic, colorfully beguiling film experiment. The main title appears in eight languages.

results.title: Boo Boo monster enters a beauty contest
results.creator_credit: Bill Cleary and Billy Budd Films
results.brief_description: A beautifully animated story about a friendly green monster who tries to change the colour of his skin and who learns he must accept himself as he really is. A rhythmic drum beat enhances the natural rhythm of the verse to which visuals are set. Animated by Tom Golden and Arnie Levey, music performed and composed by Herbert Harris.

results.title: Bonza
results.brief_description: Bonza is quite possibly the funniest Australian short film ever. It’s a look at a family life through the eyes of a blue heeler. Bonza is a family dog. He is a loyal, confident, affectionate and trusting partner to Ted, his wife Bev and their two children Terry and Katherine who all have their own problems. Ted has been retrenched after 23 years with his firm but cannot bring himself to tell his family. Katherine has just come back from a world trip to sort herself out but is no more together. Terry is doing his HSC for the third time and being forced into dentistry but all his interested in is his starring role in his school’s production of ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’. One day Bonza gets into Bev’s sleeping pills …. recriminations are soon flying thick and fast.

results.title: Bonza
results.creator_credit: David Swann, Deborah Hoare, Bonza Productions and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: Bonza is quite possibly the funniest Australian short film ever! Being the confidante to an average suburban family is finally more than a dog can bear! “A gloriously silly climax” - top acting, brilliant script and direction make this a real little barker.

results.title: Bones and muscles (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Young Japanese athletes create awareness of how the human skeletal and muscular systems work together to allow movement of the body. A frog specimen shows how the muscles in the upper arm contract and relax so that arm bones can be moved. Discusses the functions of tendons, cartilage, and ligaments and examines various bones, joints, and vertebrae.

results.title: Bonds and relationships. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country education Project-Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: A panel led by Peter Couchman, (Don Edgar, Institute of Family Affairs Jenni Strauss and Dr. Christopher Worth, Monash University and Colin Goodwin of Philip Institute) discuss the HSC literature theme which concentrates on the family and the connections which operate within families. In Part 1 the texts “Father and son” by Edmund Gosse and “Long day’s journey into night” by Eugene O’Neill are considered. Covers such topics as the changing mix of families, the stress of being oneself in a family relationship and yet still being part of a family, and the kinds of support available for people facing problems. Part 2 looks at more contemporary issues that affect family relationships. The texts “The Millstone” by Margaret Drabble and “A Very easy death” by Simone de Beauvoir are considered.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country education Project-Ministry of Education

results.title: Bonds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
This film describes why different types of bonds are used and proceeds to demonstrate various bonds. It explains that “bonding” means to arrange bricks to a definite pattern according to function. A wall in “Flemish” bond is shown and its construction demonstrated in a one brick and a one and a half brick wall. “English” bond is then dealt with followed by “Dutch” bond. English and Flemish garden wall bonds bring the film to a close.

results.title: Bon Voyage (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Upon the cruise ship “Mara” - bound for Hong Kong out of San Francisco - an oddly assorted group of travellers dine together at the Captain’s table. Here the basis of a developing web of relationships is laid and made all the more intimate and public by the inevitably close world a sea voyage creates. Starring Nigel Havers and Judy Parfitt Based on the original by Noel Coward. Rated: PG

results.title: Bombay movies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours: India”.
Vinod Kharna is one of the most popular Hindi movie stars in Bombay’s film industry. This film explores his life and work as a way of gaining insight into Indian “pop culture”.
